column1: The CDC is advising that pregnant women consider not going to the 2016 Summer Olympic Games, and there is growing evidence that the Zika virus can be sexually transmitted, so even women who stay home are at risk if their male partners are infected abroad. This creates a quandary for the 10,500 athletes expected at the Games, quite a few of whom may not even know at the time whether they or their partners are pregnant.

column1: A two-year clinical trial that compared three drugs for diabetic macular edema (DME) found that gains in vision were greater for participants receiving the drug Eylea (aflibercept) than for those receiving Avastin (bevacizumab), but only among participants starting treatment with 20/50 or worse vision. Gains after two years were about the same for Eylea and Lucentis (ranibizumab), contrary to year-one results from the study, which showed Eylea with a clear advantage. The three drugs yielded similar gains in vision for patients with 20/32 or 20/40 vision at the start of treatment.
column2: Eylea outperforms Avastin for diabetic macular edema with moderate or worse vision loss
